questions.question: What phenomenon is common in metal-organic frameworks (MOFs)?
questions.answer: Interpenetration, the entwining of multiple lattices, is common in metal-organic frameworks (MOFs).

questions.question: What is the effect of interpenetration on MOF pores?
questions.answer: Interpenetration influences the size and shape of MOF pores, which in turn modulates their molecular sieving and storage properties.

questions.question: What is autocatenation in the context of MOFs?
questions.answer: Autocatenation is a transformation of non-interpenetrated lattices into doubly interpenetrated frameworks via progressively higher degrees of interpenetration that involves no external reagents.

questions.question: How can the degree of partial interpenetration in MOFs be controlled?
questions.answer: The degree of partial interpenetration in MOFs can be controlled during synthesis by the reaction time and by solvent composition.

questions.question: What triggers autocatenation in MOFs?
questions.answer: Autocatenation in MOFs can be triggered either thermally or by shear forces.

questions.question: True or False: The ligand used to construct the MOFs is achiral.
What is the role of second harmonic generation microscopy in the study of MOFs?
questions.answer: Second harmonic generation microscopy serves as a sensitive probe of framework organization because its efficiency depends strongly on point group symmetry.

questions.question: True or False: All MOFs with controlled degrees of interpenetration allow rapid mass transport and high surface area.
What is the significance of the space group in determining the structure of MOFs?
questions.answer: The space group is significant in determining the structure of MOFs as it defines the symmetry and arrangement of the lattice in the crystal structure.

questions.question: True or False: The degree of interpenetration in MOFs is always fixed and cannot be modified after synthesis.
